# Derivatives of trigonometric, inverse, exponential, and logarithmic  functions

------

## Prerequisites:

- Limits
- Differentiation

------

As I mentioned in the Differentiation Chapter, all derivatives are pretty much found by extremely smart people at some point in history. As a TA, I find it futile to find instantaneous slope functions by hand for any purpose other than understanding derivatives. **A reasonable professor won't even ask for you to solve derivatives by hand**.

As such, I will not be going over how these functions work. You can find an extremely thorough formula and cheat sheet [here](http://tutorial.math.lamar.edu/getfile.aspx?file=B,44,N). You will most likely also be provided a cheat sheet by your professor. By the end of your first year classes, you will  have practiced these $f(x) \to f^|(x)$ conversions enough that you will have them memorized.

With that said, here are some interesting things about derivatives of each of the above function categories...

Expect for inverse functions. **Just memorize that stuff**, I have never seen a practical use for these functions that justify the time spend understanding the slope patterns.

For practice questions with full solutions, I recommend these links from Paul's Math Notes;

[Trigonometric Functions](http://tutorial.math.lamar.edu/Classes/CalcI/DiffTrigFcns.aspx)

[Inverse Functions](http://tutorial.math.lamar.edu/Classes/CalcI/DiffInvTrigFcns.aspx)

[Exponential and Logarithimic Functions](http://tutorial.math.lamar.edu/Classes/CalcI/DiffExpLogFcns.aspx) 

------

## Derivatives of Trigonometric Functions (Trig Functions)

Consider a trig function like $sin(x)$, from your algebra days you will note that this function relates to the ratio between two sides of a triangle. But in calculus, it is much easier to visualize this in a different format, as a sinusoidal wave.

![data:image/png;base64,](data:image/png;base64,)

From just looking at this graph, where are the slopes greatest, and where are the slope most flat? You would likely answer the mid points of the wave, where it crosses the x axis as the points of greatest slope. You would also likely find that the slope at the peaks and troughs are the lowest. 

Try to do a curve sketch of how the slope changes over time for this particular wave. You will find that the slope curve is exactly the same as the original curve, but has a x-axis offset of a quarter wave. Or in other words, you will find that the slope curve of a sine curve is a cosine curve! This is the reason why the derivative of a sine curve is cosine, and why the derivative of a cosine curve is a flipped sine curve,

This is **extremely** interesting, particularly to a electrical engineering/physics student. This particular math is the reason why we describes light particles as electromagnetic **waves**. 

------

## Derivatives of Exponential and Logarithmic Functions

The most interesting example of these derivatives is the much used slope function of $e^x$. You might have already learned that the slope of $e^x$ is $e^x$, or that exponential derivatives are easy to solve. What does this mean? 

1. It is an extremely useful tool to simplify other derivatives or integrals. In the world of math where slope functions may look drastically different from its the original curves, $e^x$ provides a nice consistency to build our best practices and methodologies. A good example is a more advanced topic in calculus, integration by parts. [Visit here](http://tutorial.math.lamar.edu/Classes/CalcII/IntegrationByParts.aspx) to take a quick read on what it is!
2. In the world of statistics, you can find that using derivatives on exponential or logarithmic functions are extremely useful in the sense that the provide a quick gauge on what a graph may trend towards. Take the currently happening COVID-19 pandemic. Looking just at the growth of cases on a graph for any particular region is practically useless, they are all basically an exponential curve that tells the same story. You also may have heard of scientists and smart people talk about rates of new cases per day. But what is this really? Its the slope of that original exponential curve. This particular slope is integral to disease fighting policies as it provides a realistic measurement on what sort of policies are actually effective.
